Award.AwardTitle: Youth Technology Academy: Pathway to Technology Degrees

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project builds on the results and findings of the previously funded Robotics Corridor Collaborative Project (0603427), which demonstrated that after school robotics and math programming is highly successful in motivating high school students to pursue technical and engineering studies. Yet once students who participate in such programming graduate from high schools and enroll in post-secondary institutions, they often lose interest and drop out due to lack of adequate support. The primary deliverable of this project is a pre-engineering experience, coursework, and project based instruction that includes strong, technical training with additional math preparation, enabling high school students to successfully pursue post-secondary science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) studies as soon as they arrive in college rather than being delayed by remedial coursework.

The project has five goals: (1) provide training for incumbent workers and professional development for teachers who work with students; (2) increase the number of students pursuing technical and engineering degrees upon graduation from high school; (3) reduce the need for remedial math coursework among students matriculating from high school to the college; (4) increase the number of post-secondary students successfully completing technical and engineering degrees or certificates at the college; and (5) develop 2+2+2 articulation agreements with school districts and four-year institutions.

The primary target population consists of at risk and underrepresented Cleveland Metropolitan School District high school students and community college students. The project involves enrollment of Cleveland students in coursework and after school activities that include math, robot programming, work readiness training, and other technical training. These high school and college students are being taught and mentored by high school teachers and industry experts hired as college faculty and mentored and tutored by student mentors from the college. Students also participate in a summer camp developed by the college, Kent State University, and VisualEdge. The project is mapping out a clear pathway for students to follow in pursuing their technical and engineering degrees.

Intellectual Merit: Building on the findings of prior work, this project is improving STEM education for underrepresented students and providing them with a strong support system to ensure their successful completion of post-secondary STEM education and entry into the engineering and engineering technology workforce. The project has the potential to be a student success model for underrepresented youth.

Broader Impacts: The college has a track record of working with a diverse cross section of society, especially with underrepresented and at risk urban populations. Industry representatives participate in the advisory board that helps develop curriculum for training students in the transferable work skills required in technical jobs. Project results and findings are being shared with colleagues at regional and national conferences and on the project web site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The C-PED Project addressed the need to expose under-served High School students to innovative technology and instruction primarily through project based learning.  The activities, objectives and outcomes revolved around the following core principals:

  • All high quality instruction begins with relevant professional development opportunities and persists as long as teacher support is accessible.  in other words, teacher "buy-in" is critical.
  • Project based learning is conducive to student engagement and advancement.
  • Math remediation is effective when assessment and instruction are highly correlated and presented in small dosages and during engaging instruction.
  • Thorough STEM exposure takes many forms, including building a post-secondary resume while in High School; employer models and mentors; witnessing employment opportunities; and experiencing personal success in a technological experience.

During the C-PED Program the role of the Cleveland Metropolitan School District (CMSD) instructors morphed from pupil to teacher; from recipient to contributor; and from observer to leader.  Over four years approximately sixty CMSD teachers were a part of professional development.  The Youth Technology Academy (YTA) staff at Cuyahoga Community College (Tri-C) was committed to supporting teachers' technical experiences and coaching them in project based learning.  Tech Ambassadors provided weekly support to teachers in their high schools and at the College campus on a weekly based throughout the grant period.

Over four years, 244 high school students received 708 college credits with an average GPA of 3.34.  All credits were in one of ten Engineering College courses and are part of the students' official college transcript.  Furthermore, 86% of C-PED students graduated high school (CMSD Class of 2015 - 6%) and 75% of C-PED students were enrolled in post-secondary institutions (CMSD Class of 2015 - 56%).

Student enrollment in post-secondary option classes at Tri-C through YTA has increased from 181 students (Fall 2013) to 909 students (Fall 2016).

C-PED staff was committed to creating positive, relevant post-secondary experiences for high school students in STEM related coursework.  There was particular focus on providing exposure to a variety of innovative engineering technologies through through several methodologies and platforms, including VEX and FIRST Robotics, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, CAD, Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Mechatronics.  The student experience includes personal recruitment, family inclusion, comfortable learning environment and high expectations.  C-PED Project activities underscore student's cultivation of transferable work skills through project based learning, team member responsibilities, time management, appropriate social skills and technical skill advancement. 

Advancing student math skills was a primary objective of the C-PED Project.  Priority was given to incorporating math remediation into the project based learning curriculum.  By year four, thirty short Math lessons, known as Warm Up Math 1, 2, and 3 were being used by instructors of college courses during the first thirty minutes of each class.  Lessons one through twenty focused on basic arithmetic skills and lessons twenty-one through thirty focus on Beginning Algebra.  Results were statically positive and focus groups/surveys both yielding positive feedback.

Additionally, college math principals were embedded into four basic Engineering courses.  Originating in professional development activities, a core group of CMSD teachers and YTA staff emerged to review, revamp, and rewrite course manuals.  The manual template includes course introduction and objectives, licensing information, and syllabus.  For each lesson, the template identifies math objectives, engineering objectives, relevant vocabulary, common core standards, review questions, activities and journaling experiences.  By the end of year four, this C-PED driven committee had written six manuals.  The template will be used for additional course manuals.  These manuals/workbooks are being used in the classroom by approximately 800 students during the Fall 2016 semester.

It could be alleged that all activities in the C-PED project lead to the goal of introducing, encouraging, and employing more students, especially from under-served populations, in STEM education and employment.  C-PED students were part of the larger Tri-C YTA family.  All students were enrolled in a college course each semester and all students were encouraged to participate in the many supplementary activities of YTA including Robotics Competitions, Flight Club, the Robotics Club, and Saturday robotics classes.

Additionally, wrap around, transferable work skills were taught and practiced during C-PED activities.  The YTA sponsors a varsity robotics competition each spring.  C-PED students have always been represented on the varsity team.  Members were identified through a process during which students interviewed with staff members.  The robotics team won, during the four year project many awards and accolades.  Among them are:

  • 2016 FIRST Robotics World Champions
  • Xerox Creativity Award
  • General Motors Industrial Design Award
  • Woodie Flowers Mentor Award
  • Carver Divisional Championship

Last Modified: 11/15/2016
Modified by: George Bilokonsky

The activities, objectives and outcomes revolved around the following core principals: All high quality instruction begins with relevant professional development opportunities and persists as long as teacher support is accessible. in other words, teacher "buy-in" is critical. Project based learning is conducive to student engagement and advancement. Math remediation is effective when assessment and instruction are highly correlated and presented in small dosages and during engaging instruction. Thorough STEM exposure takes many forms, including building a post-secondary resume while in High School; employer models and mentors; witnessing employment opportunities; and experiencing personal success in a technological experience. During the C-PED Program the role of the Cleveland Metropolitan School District (CMSD) instructors morphed from pupil to teacher; from recipient to contributor; and from observer to leader. Over four years approximately sixty CMSD teachers were a part of professional development. The Youth Technology Academy (YTA) staff at Cuyahoga Community College (Tri-C) was committed to supporting teachers' technical experiences and coaching them in project based learning. Tech Ambassadors provided weekly support to teachers in their high schools and at the College campus on a weekly based throughout the grant period. Over four years, 244 high school students received 708 college credits with an average GPA of 3.34. All credits were in one of ten Engineering College courses and are part of the students' official college transcript. Student enrollment in post-secondary option classes at Tri-C through YTA has increased from 181 students (Fall 2013) to 909 students (Fall 2016). There was particular focus on providing exposure to a variety of innovative engineering technologies through through several methodologies and platforms, including VEX and FIRST Robotics, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, CAD, Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Mechatronics. The student experience includes personal recruitment, family inclusion, comfortable learning environment and high expectations. Advancing student math skills was a primary objective of the C-PED Project. Priority was given to incorporating math remediation into the project based learning curriculum. Lessons one through twenty focused on basic arithmetic skills and lessons twenty-one through thirty focus on Beginning Algebra. Originating in professional development activities, a core group of CMSD teachers and YTA staff emerged to review, revamp, and rewrite course manuals. By the end of year four, this C-PED driven committee had written six manuals. The template will be used for additional course manuals. These manuals/workbooks are being used in the classroom by approximately 800 students during the Fall 2016 semester. It could be alleged that all activities in the C-PED project lead to the goal of introducing, encouraging, and employing more students, especially from under-served populations, in STEM education and employment. C-PED students have always been represented on the varsity team. Members were identified through a process during which students interviewed with staff members. The robotics team won, during the four year project many awards and accolades.
